dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: So, the initial estimate for Ukraine's reconstruction was 200 to 500 billion dollars, but after over 510 days of war, that number has probably doubled. Why should Europe be the charge on this?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: So, the initial estimate for Ukraine's reconstruction was two hundred to five hundred billion dollars, but after over five hundred ten days of war, that number has probably doubled. Why should Europe be the charge on this?
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Shortly after Russias invasion, my co-authors and I estimated that it would cost roughly 200-500 billion ($220-550 billion) to rebuild the country and called for Europe to spearhead the recovery effort. After more than 500 days of death and destruction, the projected costs have probably at least doubled.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Well, it's interesting—Europe's way more invested in Ukraine's stability than people realize. Like, they granted Ukraine candidate status for EU membership, so there's this acknowledgment that Ukraine is part of Europe's future.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Well, it's interesting-Europe's way more invested in Ukraine's stability than people realize. Like, they granted Ukraine candidate status for E U membership, so there's this acknowledgment that Ukraine is part of Europe's future.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Third, the European Union has already granted Ukraine candidate status, thereby acknowledging that the country is an integral part of Europe and should be part of the bloc.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Exactly, and the article points out that Europe actually benefited more from the fall of the Berlin Wall than the U.S. did, so they've got more at stake here if things go south.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Exactly, and the article points out that Europe actually benefited more from the fall of the Berlin Wall than the U.S. did, so they've got more at stake here if things go south.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: While the US benefited enormously from the fall of the Berlin Wall in 1989, European countries reaped far greater rewards.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, and then there's the whole issue of U.S. support potentially wavering after the 2024 election. Populist movements in both parties are really turning inward, so long-term financial aid might not be a priority.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, and then there's the whole issue of U.S. support potentially wavering after the twenty twenty four election. Populist movements in both parties are really turning inward, so long-term financial aid might not be a priority.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Both Democrats and Republicans are increasingly embracing populist stances, and todays populists focus mostly on domestic issues, with little concern for the rest of the world.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Right, and Europe's been free-riding on U.S. defense spending for decades. The U.S. spends twice as much as a share of GDP—if Europe just matched that, they'd have an extra $300 billion a year, more than enough to cover reconstruction.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Right, and Europe's been free-riding on U.S. defense spending for decades. The U.S. spends twice as much as a share of G D P-if Europe just matched that, they'd have an extra three hundred dollars billion a year, more than enough to cover reconstruction.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The US currently spends twice as much as EU member states on national defense as a share of GDP. Conversely, if Europe raised spending to US levels, it would be spending at least $300 billion per year more, easily enough to pay for reconstructing Ukraine and much more.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: But uh, some European countries like France, Italy, Spain—they've contributed very little so far, according to that Kiel Institute report. Even the recent EU pledge is mostly loans Ukraine can't repay.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: But uh, some European countries like France, Italy, Spain-they've contributed very little so far, according to that Kiel Institute report. Even the recent E U pledge is mostly loans Ukraine can't repay.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Nevertheless, a recent report by the Kiel Institute for the World Economy underscored just how little some European countries, such as France, Italy, and Spain, have contributed to the Ukrainian war effort. While the EU has recently pledged to provide Ukraine with an additional 50 billion by 2027, only a third of this sum will be given as outright grants.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Which is kind of wild when you think about it. I mean, France's own report said they'd run out of ammo in weeks in a serious conflict—their readiness isn't exactly reassuring.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Which is kind of wild when you think about it. I mean, France's own report said they'd run out of ammo in weeks in a serious conflict-their readiness isn't exactly reassuring.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: But a report by Frances National Assembly in February, which suggests the country would exhaust its existing ammunition within weeks in the event of an intense armed conflict, does not inspire much confidence in European countries military readiness.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: And yet, there's this historic responsibility. The article argues Europe has to step up even if it means taking on debt or slower growth for themselves.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: And yet, there's this historic responsibility. The article argues Europe has to step up even if it means taking on debt or slower growth for themselves.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: But European countries must come to terms with their historic responsibility to lead this effort, even if it means higher debt and slower growth for their own economies in the future.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Do you think they will, though? I mean, the political will seems shaky.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Do you think they will, though? I mean, the political will seems shaky.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: It's tough, but if they don't, and the U.S. pulls back, Ukraine's really in a bind. Reconstruction isn't just about money—it's about stability for the whole region.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: It's tough, but if they don't, and the U.S. pulls back, Ukraine's really in a bind. Reconstruction isn't just about money-it's about stability for the whole region.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: For sure. And with nuclear escalation looming, the stakes couldn't be higher.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: For sure. And with nuclear escalation looming, the stakes couldn't be higher.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Similarly, Europe has more to lose from a return to the pre-war status quo, not to mention from the looming threat of nuclear escalation.
